description.narrative:
In Ethiopia, this Reconstruction programme will focus on the following outcomes:
1. Increased level of implementation of local agreements, decreased dowry levels and increased mutual respect and cooperation in various projects among the tribes and clans living in the targeted areas of Gambella and Jonglei, with special attention for the role of women and of youth.
2. Inclusive improved food security through increased availability and optimal and collaborative use of available livelihood resources and increased services among the various tribes and clans living in the targeted areas of Gambella and Jonglei with special attention for the role of women and of youth.
In Gambella Region, Ethiopia: all population of Wantawo and Akobo Woredas: around 50,000 persons (about 8,300 households).
In this programme ZOA will contribute to enhance stability and safety as preconditions for people to rebuild their lives and strengthen their livelihood strategies.

participating-org.narrative: While in Ethiopia the two targeted Woredas have limited presence of (I)NGO’s, there are several local structures and institutions that the programme can and will tap into and to which the programme will offer capacity building support: • Local Administrations at Regional, Zonal, Woreda and Kebele level: DPFSA, bureaus of Agriculture, Water, Health, Education • Woreda Council • Woreda Justice Bureau • Woreda Women and Children Affairs Department • Traditional elders and traditional structures for peace/settlement negotiations • Youth and Women representatives • Churches (more than 80% of population in the area belongs to a protestant denomination).

activity-date.narrative: The project received initial approval by the ministry of Foreign Affairs on 28th June 2012 for a total amount of 64% of the proposed budget at the time of submission in March 2012. ZOA was then asked to submit a revised project plan by latest 15th September 2012. The Ministry decided on the revised plan on 16th November 2012, after which ZOA started further implementation of the project. ZOA found it best to not start the revised project immediately after submission in September 2012 so not to run the risk of beginning project work on a wrong footing, we considered the operational risks of starting the project without having received the donor’s ultimate directions, too high. Therefore, we could only start full project preparations in second half of November and were left with six weeks in 2012 to this effect. The extent of project activity in 2012 has been limited; work has focused on project preparations mainly. (Actual operations took off in 2013.)

policy-marker.narrative: This ZOA programme will contribute to human safety by addressing the factors that can be influenced positively.

description.narrative: Improved capacity for enhanced household productivity in agriculture (Ethiopia and South Sudan) and fishing (Ethiopia only).
At least 50% of 1000 targeted households report that they fish for making part of their income for a period of 3 months per year.

comment.narrative: N/A

For 2014 not implemented and it has been decided to shift budget from this activity to the seed supply (see indicator 2.1.2). So this indicator will not be targeted anymore by the project and therefore it can be removed.
Not implemented because of the budget shift: see 2014 measurement.
Not implemented because of the budget shift: see 2014 measurement.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, at least 25% of beneficiary households engaged in agriculture in target communities have added one crop to their portfolio (households having improved access to land) or have added at least one seed variety (households having limited access to land) over the baseline.

comment.narrative: N/A
25% of beneficiaries have added one crop or one seed variety added to portfolio compared to baseline
2-days workshop was held by trainer of DPFA for 16 participants of different government bureaus and traditional leaders.
25% of beneficiaries have added one crop or one seed variety added to portfolio compared to baseline
37.6% of households that grow their own crops added a new crop last year. 27.9% of households that grow their own crops added a new seed variety last year. 32.75% is the average
37.6% of households that grow their own crops added a new crop last year. 27.9% of households that grow their own crops added a new seed variety. 32.75% is the average
25% of beneficiaries have added one crop or one seed variety added to portfolio compared to baseline

Sorghum and Maize were distributed in 2013 and 2014 and no new crop or new variety was introduced. This was agreed upon with the Regional Agricultural Bureau and the beneficiaries. For 2015 it is planned to target flooding affected households in Akobo with additional seed supply

description.narrative: By the end of the project, average crop production of beneficiary households in target communities has increased by 10% over baseline.

comment.narrative: Nuer Jikany - maize production: 319 kilo/HH; sorghum production: 176 kilo/HH. Anyuak - maize production: 174 kilo/HH; sorghum production: 177 kilo/HH.
10% increase when compared to baseline

71.2% of the households grow their own crops. Sorghum production: 4.4% of households grow their own sorghum, 185.4 kilo average per household that grow sorghum. 99.3% of households grow their own maize, 356.9 kilo average per household that grow maize. 1% of households grow their own millet, 212 kilo average per household that grow millet. Maize production grew with 11.8% over baseline. Sorghum production grew with 5.3% over baseline (average is 8.55%). This is only measured for Nuer (Jikany and Lou), Anuak could not be measured in 2015.
10% increase when compared to baseline
83 community members (32 female) of the different sub-clans, mainly from Gagwang, Gajok and Anuak, received improved agricultural traning.
10% increase when compared to baseline

Due to excessive flooding most of the farmers lost their crops in 2014. During a survey done in February it was reported that on average the HH harvested 389 kg maize and 299 kg sorghum. This contradicts with the information we received earlier from the Agricultural Office and from observation reports. In 2015 we will work on more reliable production monitoring.
10% increase when compared to baseline

Maize production grew with 11.8% over baseline. Sorghum production grew with 5.3% over baseline. This is only measured for Nuer (Jikany and Lou), Anuak could not be measured in 2016 since they were all evacuated from the two woredas due to conflict. Average increase is 8.55%

description.narrative: Improved capacity of local government in 2 Woredas to facilitate stakeholders in the target areas to develop capacity for the outputs 1.1 and 1.2.

By the end of the project at least 50 government and partner staff who have participated in the training, report back on examples of successful application of improved community cohesion skills (this includes initial early warning systems against cattle raiding).

comment.narrative: N/A

From 4-8 April 2016 a community cohesion & conflict transformation training was given by an external consultant. This training was for staff from the Regional, Zonal and Woreda Justice Bureaus. Including the trainer and two ZOA staffs, 12 people participated. The training was decided to hold in Jimma, since the group was a mix of Nuer and Agnuak people. In Gambella the tension between the two groups was too high to put them together in one meeting hall. To prevent problems, the training was held outside Gambella. The evaluation showed that Government staff members have been closely involved in community cohesion activities. All staff members who attended one of the trainings reported back they learned what community cohesion means, how they can talk with others about community cohesion and conflict and resolve conflicts.

Government staff have been involved in community cohesion activities. Overall everyone who we spoke to and who attended one of the trainings reported back they learned what community cohesion means, how they can talk with others about community cohesion and conflict and how to aware others about community cohesion.

USAID: Government staff (especially Justice Bureau and Justice Office: 8) staff is part of the implementation of the project. The indication is that the staff has improved capacity. However this is not measured yet. In 2015 with BUZA funding 30 government staff will be trained on community cohesion and 20 government staff will be joining the CC-agreements monitoring visits which contains training
Will be implemented by JB in 2014 - 2016.

description.narrative: Improved capacity of relevant local tribal and clan leaders, churches, other organizations and local government to prevent and mitigate for issues and sustain cohesion.
By the end of the project, youth are actively included in at least 40% of inter-group efforts in the targeted counties/woredas

comment.narrative: During the baseline survey the youth in ETH (and SDN) were not involved in inter-group efforts/agreements.

For USAID in 2014 youth were included, however during signing of agreements and by tracking down the CCLC members on woreda and kebele level the age of the person was not written down. This will be improved in 2015 as well for the implementation of BUZA activities.

Youth groups are actively participated in conflict resolution in both Wanthoa and Akobo Woreda. Youth are members of CCLCs. And youth are involved in Sport 4 Unity, sport teams to create cohesion in the Woredas. Almost 85% achieved.
Youth groups come together in Wanthoa and Akobo Woreda. Youth are members of CCLCs. And youth are involved in Sport 4 Unity, sport teams to create cohesion in the Woredas. % is not measured.
Youth stigmatized as gangsters identified and involved in livelihood and sports activities. This output is implemented by JB in 2014 - 2016.

description.narrative: By the end of the project 100 tribal leaders, church leaders, youth group / association leaders, women group / association leaders and local government staff capacitated to lead discussions and organise campaigns for making dowry prices and debts more manageable and adjusting bylaws.

comment.narrative: N/A: No organized discussions around dowry prices and debts existed at time of baseline

In 2014 funded by USAID the two Woreda Community Cohesion Leadership Committees (60 members) were trained to lead discussions and organise campaigns. These members include pastors, youth, women and local leaders. For BUZA in 2015 this set up of WCCLC will be followed and members capacitated. Besides this 4 Justice Bureau staff and 4 Justice Office staffs are capacitated.

In 2015 different sessions took place to capacitate community cohesion leadership committees, women groups and youth. The community cohesion working groups had different meetings: end of session meetings (3 & 20 Feb, 270 & 300 participants); about natural resource use (23 Feb & 21 March, 238 & 253 participants); working group meetings (7-9 May and 11-13 May, 38 & 380 participants) and a awareness creation meeting (2-3 June, 40 participants). The Peace facilitators have been trained in February: 7 in Akobo and 4 in Wanthoa. Total no. of participants = 1530. Next to that dissemination and agreement ceremonies took place (March 25 - April 6, 235 participants and 28-30 April, 174 participants). At least 4 Justice Bureau staff were involved in all activities.

In 2015 different sessions took place to capacitate community cohesion leadership committees, women groups and youth. The community cohesion working groups had different meetings: end of session meetings (3 & 20 Feb, 70 & 300 participants); about natural resource use (23 Feb & 21 March, 238 & 253 participants); working group meetings (7-9 May and 11-13 May, 38 & 380 participants) and a awareness creation meeting (2-3 June, 40 participants). The Peace facilitators have been trained in February: 7 in Akobo and 4 in Wanthoa. Total no. of participants = 1530. Next to that, dissemination and agreement ceremonies took place (March 25 - April 6, 235 participants and 28-30 April, 174 participants). At least 4 Justice Bureau staff were involved in all activities.
Relationships built with the Nuer Christian Youth Association. Will be worked upon further by the JB in 2014 - 2016.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, functional systems are in place in all targeted counties/Woreda to follow up on local/regional peace agreements.

comment.narrative: N/A: Reference point is one committee (Nuer Council of Churches) at time of baseline study.

In 2014 funded by USAID in each kebele (12), five community cohesion working groups with each 40 members (total 2400 members M1278/F1122), one kebele community cohesion leadership committee (KCCLC) is established. In both woredas a woreda peace leadership committee is functional. For BUZA/EKN this will be done in 2015 for 17 kebeles in Wanthoa and 15 kebeles in Akobo.

In each Kebele there is a Community Cohesion Leadership Committee functional. For BUZA these are 12 Kebeles, 6 Kebeles in each Woreda. CCLC are established as well on Woreda level; both Wanthoa and Akobo have a Woreda CCLC. The CCLCs consist of community elders and leaders, women, youth.
LoU signed with the Regional Justice Bureau (JB) for implementation of all community cohesion activities.

Woreda CCLCs in Akobo and Wanthoa, Kebele CCLCs in different Kebeles, CC Facilitators follow up and report to ZOA and Justice Bureau. Women groups and youth groups raise awareness in Kebeles. CC Working Group is in place in Wanthoa.

description.narrative: By the end of the project 50% of targeted communities have developed initial early warning systems against cattle raiding.

comment.narrative: The Early Warning System does not function anymore
EWS is planned for 2015; see adjusted plan for 2015
EWS will be worked on by the JB in 2014 - 2016.

Early warning study is done in December 2015. The report stated that the communities have their own Early Warning System which has been used for years. The study is discussed in an interactive workshop with the CCLC members from Akobo and Wanthoa. The CCLC members train the other members in their committees. The CCLCs are now the ones that notice, discuss and report conflict. They solve conflicts together with the community and come together on regular basis (weekly or monthly). A handbook has been published that can be used as training material for the governmental Justice Bureau, to train their own staff and the CCLCs. 100% achieved.
Not yet done. Early Warning System training is about to happen (May 2016). Traditional Early Warning Systems are in place. People know who to warn in case of a problem/conflict.

description.narrative: Inclusive improved food security through increased availability and optimal and collaborative use of available livelihood resources and increased services among the various tribes and clans living in the targeted areas of Gambella and Jonglei, with special attention for the role of women and of youth.
By the end of the project, access to a safe and reliable source of drinking water has increased by 30% among 8.000 beneficiaries (1.000 households) in the Woredas of Akobo and Wanthoa

comment.narrative: 14% of the people have access to water through hand pumps and piped water during the rainy season, 13% have access during the dry season.
30% increase when compared to baseline

0% improvement; Drilling was started but not successful in 2014. Temporary solution was set up by the help of UNICEF through Emergency Water Systems. A feasibility study needs to show what the most cost efficient alternative solution will be for reaching our objective.
30% increase when compared to baseline

4 water boreholes are dug in Wanthoa in 4 different Kebeles in 2014. In Akobo two EMWAT systems are still running. After carrying out a feasibility study on bore holes in Akobo it turned out to be impossible with the current transportation means and the conflicts in South Sudan to transport the necessary equipment to Akobo to create new water points. Therefore, Sawyer water filters have been distributed on a household level (Number). In Wanthoa the Water Department said every 8 km there is a water point in the Woreda. This means 100% of the people has access to safe drinking water.
30% increase when compared to baseline

4 water boreholes are dug in Wanthoa in 4 different Kebeles in 2014. In Akobo two EMWAT systems are still running. We are still working on making water pumps in Akobo, feasibility study has been done. In Wanthoa the Water Department said every 8 km there is a water point in the Woreda. That means 100% of the people has access to safe drinking water.
30% increase when compared to baseline
Is an outcome indicator, not output

10 point increase in FCS

10 point increase in FCS
FCS is 49.56, which is 21.86 points over baseline score (27.7). Since the FCS is not measured per person, it is not known if 80% of 1,000 beneficiary households show improvement.

description.narrative: Increased access to safe water and to education
By the end of the project, the percentage of households that use water from hand pumps as the primary source of household water consumption has increased by at least 30% in Wanthoa and Akobo Woredas.

comment.narrative: Jikany Nuer: 25 % during rainy season and 21 % during dry season; Anyuak: 0 %
30% increase compared to baseline

62% use hand pumps or piped water during the dry season. 58% use hand pumps or piped water during the rainy season. 40% use hand pump during the dry season, 38% use hand pump during the rainy season. Average usage of handpumps = 49.5%. Compared to the average baseline (23%), this is an average increase of 26.5% (49.5 - 23 = 26.5%)
30% increase compared to baseline: Jikany Nuer: 55 % during rainy season and 51 % during dry season; Anyuak: 30 %

62% use hand pumps or piped water during the dry season. 58% use hand pumps or piped water during the rainy season. 40% use hand pump during the dry season, 38% use hand pump during the rainy season. The Emergency Water System (EMWAT) has been maintained and operated in Akobo, no bore holes could be drilled in this area. Therefore, Sawyer water filters have been provided on the household level for which people use water from the river. Average usage of handpumps = 49.5%. Compared to the average baseline (23%), this is an average increase of 26.5% (49.5 - 23 = 26.5%)
30% increase compared to baseline
In 2014 funded by EKN in Wanthoa 4 handpumps are installed and functional and handed over to the community. For BUZA this is planned for 2015/2016
30% increase compared to baseline.

description.narrative: 2 Water Departments capacitated through technical assistance and training.

comment.narrative: N/A
In 2014 funded by EKN in Wanthoa 4 Water Committees are esablished and trained; The two water departement are planned to be trained by external or ZOA wash expert in 2015 under BUZA project.
In both Akobo and Wanthoa the Water Department received training in 2015 and 2016, on overall management of the bore holes, the EMWAT system and the use of Sawyer water filters.
In both Akobo and Wanthoa the Water Department received training in 2015. No other assistance.
The operation linked to water drilling will be implemented within the first and second quarters of the year 2014.

description.narrative: At end of the program 50% of vocational trainees from the targeted payams/Woreda capacitated to earn income from their acquired skills.

comment.narrative: N/A

29 Teacher of Trainers who were trained in 2014 are still functioning (15 from Wanthoa + 6 IDPs from Akobo, 10 from Akobo). In 2015 they trained 164 VSTs in Wanthoa and 164 VSTs in Akobo. Recently the trainees got their start up material, in December 2015.

In 2014 32 people were trained to function as trainer for the rest of their community. For BUZA 180 beneficaries for the vocational skills training under this project are selected to be trained in 2015/2016
Selection process for a training centre was started.

VSLs have been trained in five agriculture based vocational skills trainings; improved beekeeping, improved home gardening & vegetable crop production, improved fishing production, poultry and small scale dairy farming.

description.narrative: Two schools reconstructed and establishment of PTAs

comment.narrative: N/A: 57% of respondents has school in village and 66% of respondents reported that their children attend school (combined figures for both people groups).

One school is constructed in Burebey (Wanthoa), one is constructed in Tergol (Akobo). Both schools have a PTA which are functional. 611 (392 Male, 219 Female) students are enrolled in Burebey, 732 (612 Male, 120 Female) students are enrolled in Tergol.

One school is constructed in Burebey (Wanthoa), one is constructed in Tergol (Akobo). Both schools have a PTA which are functional. 611 (392 Male, 219 Female) students are enrolled in Burebey, 732 (612 Male, 120 Female) students are enrolled in Tergol.
Two schools are under construction, one in Akobo and one in Burbey. PTAs will be established in 2015

description.narrative: Increased level of implementation of local agreements, decreased dowry levels and increased mutual respect and cooperation in various projects among the tribes and clans living in the targeted areas of Gambella and Jonglei, with special attention for the role of women and of youth.
In the targeted counties/ woredas 70% of the action points flowing from five local/regional agreements are actively followed up on, with a focus on active participation of youth.

comment.narrative: N/A

In 2014 funded by USAID: 12 kebeles (6 in Wanthoa/ 6 in Akobo) signed local agreements and bylaws are in place. BUZA/EKN activities start in 2015 in 32 additional kebeles using the experiences of 2014 community cohesion work with the USAID funding
Is an outcome indicator, not output

There is a community cohesion agreement with 17 articles, signed in December 2015 in 2 Woredas: Akobo and Wanthoa. There is also a natural resource agreement signed with 8 bylaws. The different bylaws and the agreements are respected and turn out to bring community cohesion in the Woredas (according to all interviews and focus groups done). Youth participate in youth groups and in the different Community Cohesion Leadership Committees.

There is a community cohesion agreement with 17 articles, signed in December 2015 in 2 Woredas:Akobo and wanthoa. this is translated, adjusted and signed again in August and September 2016. There is also a natural resource agreement signed with 8 bylaws. The different bylaws and the agreements are respected and turn out to bring peace in the Woredas (according to all interviews and focus groups done). Youth participate in youth groups and in the different Community Cohesion Leadership Committees.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, at least 30% of the targeted beneficiaries indicates an improvement in their perception of shared identity and shared values with other groups.

comment.narrative: Value is 1.38 on a five points scale.
30% of beneficiaries indicates an improvement in their perception
Is an outcome indicator not output
Value is 1,44 on scale -2 to 2. It has improved with 0,06 points over baseline value.
Value is 1,44 on scale -2 to 2. It has improved with 0,06 points over baseline value.
30% of beneficiaries indicates an improvement in their perception
Value is 1.79 on a five points scale during February 2015. 450 respondents.

description.narrative: Increased opportunities for positive inter-tribe/clan interaction on livelihood related matters, community cohesion, dowry reduction, sports.

By the end of the project 11 (5 in Gambella; 6 in Jonglei) projects proposed and being implemented that promote inclusion and mutual respect. These projects must require inter-tribe/clan interaction and can deal with matters such as access to water, grazing land, trust building or campaigns aimed at making dowry prices and/or debts more manageable.

comment.narrative: N/A
12 Small scale tender projects (6 in Wanthoa and 6 in Akobo) are inter-tribe and inter-clan. They are Vegetable and Fishery groups (6/6) and know about the resource agreements and respect them.
Community conversations held and community cohesion (CC) faciliators were selected. 12 in Akobo Woreda and 12 in Wanthoa Woreda. These CC facilitators must be recognized by the JB.

In Akobo one fishing group and one fishing & vegetable group were setup consisting of Anywaa and Nuer members; In Wanthoa one fishing group, one fishing & vegetable group and one vegetable were established. From the last three it is unknown if these consist of members of different clans/ tribes. Will be sorted out in 2015.

To enhance livelihood improvement of primary project beneficiaries in terms of capacity building, livelihoods/VSLA facilitators have been trained and are facilitating VSLA and other livelihood activities at the community level particularly VSLA groups.12 Small scale tender projects (6 in Wanthoa and 6 in Akobo) are inter-tribe and inter-clan. They are Vegetable and Fishery groups (6/6) and know about the resource agreements and respect them.

description.narrative: By the end of the project 6 (3 in Gambella; 3 in Jonglei) inter-tribe/clan sports competitions held.

comment.narrative: N/A
Fourteen sport teams organized and supported with materials, of which six soccer teams, six volleyball teams and two basketball teams.

In Wanthoa 2 sport competitions were held before 2015 and 1 in 2015. In Akobo 2 competitions have been organised, 16 sport teams in total are set up in Akobo in different age groups for volleyball, football and basketball.

One big sports competition was held in Wanthoa woreda; people from different clans/ tribes showed up to watch the soccer games that were played among the sports teams that are built up by youth from different clans and tribes

Sport competition is a key strategy to improve the people to people relations. Therefore different sports competitions were held in Akobo and Wanthoa. In Wanthoa 3 sport competitions were organized in the total project period. In Akobo 2 competitions have been organised, 16 sport teams in total are set up in Akobo in different age groups for volleyball, football and basketball.

description.narrative: The project received initial approval by the ministry of Foreign Affairs on 28th June 2012 for a total amount of 64% of the proposed budget at the time of submission in March 2012. ZOA was then asked to submit a revised project plan by latest 15th September 2012. The Ministry decided on the revised plan on 16th November 2012, after which ZOA started further implementation of the project. ZOA found it best to not start the revised project immediately after submission in September 2012 so not to run the risk of beginning project work on a wrong footing, we considered the operational risks of starting the project without having received the donor’s ultimate directions, too high. Therefore, we could only start full project preparations in second half of November and were left with six weeks in 2012 to this effect. The extent of project activity in 2012 has been limited; work has focused on project preparations mainly. (Actual operations took off in 2013.) The necessary revision of the project plan for Ethiopia was governed by the strict 70--30 division on direct--indirect costs in humanitarian projects. This rule is a directive by the authorities for all NGOs that are active in the country. As a consequence, ZOA had to make cuts equally in the direct and indirect costs components. The project aims to support communities in very remote areas which are challenging to get to. With the 40% budget reduction, ZOA Ethiopia faced the challenge to meet all logistics needs. The 40% reduction had also directly affected the targeted number of beneficiaries. However, ZOA Ethiopia managed to attract other funding for this geographical area, through which these beneficiaries remained to be included in ZOA’s humanitarian services aiming at human security improvement.

title.narrative: Not applicable for this annual report: see narrative above
